To the Editor: Thanks to Frederick Turner (''Autumn Is Mellow Deep in Normandy,'' Sept. 10) for reminding me of a visit, in 1976, to the splendid Calvados countryside and an overnight at the same Auberge du Vieux Puits in Pont-Audemer.
In those days the kitchen boasted one star in Michelin (no longer the case), and lived up to it.

Dinner, served in a charming little room with beamed ceiling and fireplace and copper pots hanging on the wall, included trout in a Champagne cream sauce, Calvados sorbet, lamb in pastry, the holy trinity of Normandy cheese (Camembert, Livarot and Pont l'Eveque) and, naturally, apple tart. Breakfast was a bountiful offering of croissants, brioche, bread and toast, along with real tea.
Our bill for everything was under $50. Those were the days.
